subject: 10yr JGBs are lower 40 ticks and 10yr JGB yields are up 6 basis points at a near 6-month high following the reports on Friday the BoJ may discuss potential policy changes at its meeting including the yield curve target to allow for long-term natural rise

10yr JGBs are lower 40 ticks and 10yr JGB yields are up 6 basis points at a near 6-month high following the reports on Friday the BoJ may discuss potential policy changes at its meeting including the yield curve target to allow for long-term natural rise
South Korea is to increase nuclear power run rates amid heatwave
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Wesfarmers (WES AT) expects Coles demerger completed by November, Tokyo Steel (5423 JT) reports Q1 net declined but revenue increased
content:
AUSTRALIA

CSR (CSR AT)
- Co. is reportedly eyeing a quick sale of its Viridian glass unit and are expected to launch an international sales campaign. (The Australian)

Nufarm (NUF AT)
- Co. guides FY18 underlying EBIT to increase to between AUD 255mln-270mln, Co. says it expects Australia and New Zealand operations to be significantly impacted by extended dry weather conditions. (Newswires)

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- Co. expects Coles unit demerger to be completed by November in which it will retain 15% of the Co. and 50% of flybuys. Co. also stated that shareholders will receive one Coles share for every Wesfarmers share and that Coles will have a dividend payout ratio of between 80%-90%. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT)
- Co. unit BT Financial announced reduction to its platform pricing. (Newswires)

Yancoal Australia (YAL AT)
- Co. Q2 saleable coal output rose 102% Y/Y to 9.16mln tons. (Newswires)


JAPAN

Oji Holdings (361 JT)
- Co. is expected to report Q1 operating profit over JPY 25.0bln due to increased margins. (Newswires)

Tokyo Steel (5423 JT)
- Co. Q1 net JPY 3.86bln vs. Prev. JPY 4.32bln Y/Y, rev. JPY 47.6bln vs. Prev. JPY 39.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Casino related
- Japan’s Diet enacted the casino gambling bill on Friday which would permit integrated resorts to be built in 3 locations. (Newswires)

Other News
- There were reports on Friday that the BoJ are to discuss potential policy changes at their meeting this month, according to sources. The reports suggested that the changes would be made on the basis of sustainability not tightening and that the debate could see a change to their yield curve target to allow a long-term natural rise. Furthermore, reports noted the central bank could tweak the way they buy ETFs or JGBs and that interest rate target changes could also be discussed. However, there were comments over the weekend from BoJ Governor Kuroda who stated that he absolutely knew nothing regarding the basis of the reports and that remarks would be inappropriate given the proximity of the bank’s monetary policy meeting. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Asiana Airlines (020560 KS)
- Co. will further compensate passengers for the in-flight meal disruption and flight schedule delays with mileage points on top of the previously announced transportation credit vouchers. (Newswires)

Hana Financial (086790 KS)
- Co. Q2 net KRW 635.3bln vs. Exp. 604.4bln, rev. KRW 11.3tln vs. Prev. KRW 4.56tln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. is said to have reached a deal with South Korean union. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. consented to conclusive arbitration including compensation for workers at its semiconductor and display plants that contracted serious illnesses including leukemia. (Newswires)

Other News
- South Korea plans to begin process this year for reconnecting rail and road links with North Korea. (Yonhap)

subject: Barclays says trade of the week is short USD/JPY with a target of 108.10 and stop at 113.40
China government researcher urges for taxes to be cut in China
Wesfarmers (WES AT) expects Coles unit demerger to be completed by November
UK Brexit Secretary Raab says government must be ready in the event of a no-deal Brexit
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights Include Singapore CPI
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA

There were reports on Friday that the BoJ are to discuss potential policy changes at their meeting this month, according to sources. The reports suggested that the changes would be made on the basis of sustainability not tightening and that the debate could see a change to their yield curve target to allow a long-term natural rise. Furthermore, reports noted the central bank could tweak the way they buy ETFs or JGBs and that interest rate target changes could also be discussed. However, there were comments over the weekend from BoJ Governor Kuroda who stated that he absolutely knew nothing regarding the basis of the reports and that remarks would be inappropriate given the proximity of the bank’s monetary policy meeting. (Newswires)
 

UK

Brussels rejected the UK proposal regarding how to govern its financial services access post-Brexit, with EU chief Brexit negotiator Barnier stating the enhanced equivalence plan would result in EU losing its decision-making autonomy. (FT)

EU officials and diplomats stated a fundamental change in UK politics would be needed for there to be any value for the EU in an extension of the UK’s membership. (Guardian)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab has accused the EU of acting irresponsibly by warning of the risks posed to its citizens in the UK under a no-deal exit. Raab has also been reported to say the UK could refuse to pay its GBP 39bln “divorce bill” unless the EU agrees to a binding framework for a future trade deal. (Sunday Times)

According to a YouGov poll, UK PM May is facing an unprecedented political crisis as voters are implacably opposed to her Brexit plan and are prepared to turn to UKIP or parties of the far right. (Sunday Times)


EU

French President Macron is planning a reshuffle of the cabinet and other functions after his security officer was charged with assault on protestors, according to sources. (Newswires)

French Finance Minister Le Maire stated that a trade war has already begun and that the EU will have no option but to retaliate if the US imposes more tariffs. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Greece at B+; Outlook revised to Positive from Stable, affirmed Czech Republic at AA-; Outlook Stable and affirmed Russia at BBB-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed France at AA; Outlook Stable, affirmed Austria at AA+; Outlook revised to Positive from Stable and affirmed Canada at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

US Baker Hughes Rig Count (20/Jul) total rigs fell by 8 to 1046. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo said North Korea is illegally smuggling petroleum products which goes against UN sanctions, while he also noted that coal smuggling must also be stopped. (Newswires)
 

US

US President Trump said on Friday that the US is ready to impose tariffs on all USD 505bln of Chinese import goods, while he also commented that China, the EU and others have been manipulating their currencies and interest rates lower. Furthermore, US President Trump also questioned why the Fed is raising rates and stated tightening now hurts all that the US has done. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated G20 is completely united on broad systemic issues and that they are seeing light at the end of the tunnel on trade disputes, while he also hopes to get a NAFTA agreement negotiated in near future. Mnuchin had also stated that he is available anytime China wants to negotiate meaningful changes for its trade practices and that investors shouldn’t be worried about a currency war. Furthermore, Mnuchin stated that US President Trump will come to Buenos Aires for G20 leaders' summit, while there were comments from Japanese Finance Minister Aso who said he spoke with Mnuchin on tariffs but couldn’t reveal what was stated. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US stocks finished subdued as US President Trump renewed his trade rhetoric on China in which he suggested that that the US is ready to impose tariffs on all USD 505bln of Chinese import goods. In terms of earnings, Microsoft Corp (MSFT) beat on EPS and revenue and its Intelligent Cloud revenue was higher by 23% to USD 9.6bln, and it was ranked the second largest company in the cloud market. Ex-Dow component General Electric (GE) beat on both top and bottom line and traded higher pre-market however gains were erased, and the stock trended lower throughout Friday’s session. Honeywell (HON) provided a stellar earnings report and beat on both top and bottom line as well as boosting its sales, segment margin and free cash flow guidance for 2018. Skechers lost over a quarter of their market cap after their same store sales missed expectations at 4.5% (Exp. 5.2%) and reported EPS of 19c, 12c below wall street’s expectations; SKX also lowered its Q3 EPS and revenue guidance. SPX -0.09% at 2802, NDX -0.03% at 7350, DJI -0.03% at 25058.

The yield curve bear-steepened on Friday There was further selling in the complex on reports that Trump was concerned that the Fed would hike twice more in 2018. 30yr yields ending the session higher by c.6bps, whilst the 2yr only higher by c.1bps. Volume was decent across the complex. Yield spreads were wider 2s30s by c.7bps, 2s10s by c.5bps and 5s30s by c.4bps. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 10 ticks lower at 119-31+.

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
